lifting away from you in terms of provisioning the cluster standing up yourself making the right decisions
about how do I pick the right instances to run the control plane how do I set up the right security configuration
a lot of that those decisions and that cognitive overhead we try to take away from you and make it much easier to get

solve the problem you're actually handling orthogonal concerns like how do you provision your application how do

so why why manages just to get rid of some of the heavy lifting why are people
looking for a managed version instead of just their do-it-yourself on easy to version yeah I think it's an interesting
question so one of the things that we'd love to see is like there's a CNC F statistic statistic that says that 57%
of kubernetes workloads run on AWS today and that's before us releasing a service to help people do that so there's a lot
of enthusiasm and passion in the community today around running Cooper net on AWS and so we're really excited to be
a part of that community but also try to make it easier for customers to get up and running more quickly so you know
this is a multi-faceted thing for us since we want to build a service that lets you run production grade workloads
but also contribute back to this community and you know just really help people do what they're passionate about
doing which is running applications on kubernetes and we think we're on our way to doing that so I think part of part of what's
important here is so kubernetes is open source you can run it in a ton of different places how do you go about
making that kind of like amazonian so how do I do some of the things that I'm already familiar with in AWS like
networking and security and things like that how do those fit in with with uks so
we've written a couple of integrations well actually taking a step back we really want to let people use the
open-source tooling that they already know and love with kubernetes but at the same time be able to use AWS integrations in certain places with
kubernetes if they want to so a couple of things that we've built in terms of like open source projects that are out
with eks today first of all we the C&I plugin which is the container networking interface and that lets you get VPC IP
addresses for your kubernetes pods so you don't really have to think about what networking stack do you want to use
it's kind of provided with eks for you and then secondly we've also built integration with i.m so for
authentication to your kubernetes api endpoint you can use I am for the

so welcome back so we're here live from Amazon HQ talking about the launch of
Amazon eks it's now generally available so the elastic container service for kubernetes I'm joined here in the studio
by Charles the CTO of GoDaddy here to talk about running kubernetes and AWS
and how GoDaddy is using Amazon eks to move from running infrastructure and
their data centers to the cloud so Charles welcome thank you so first things first can you tell us a little
bit about what GoDaddy is and what they do so good idea is a place where people go with new ideas new businesses new
initiatives to basically build their online presence so they buy domain names from us they build websites with us
they host email they can even do bookkeeping with us we are one of the largest providers and most of those
categories we have about seventeen and a half million customers seventy six million domains millions and millions of
websites you know through tools such as our own go central website editing tool as well as manage WordPress so that's
keeping millions of websites honest I think is no small feat so how do you how do you do that where are they all hosted
so right now all of our infrastructure is on-premise and obviously we are going to be moving a lot of that to Amazon as
a cloud provider today if I use just the simple example of manage WordPress that's something that we really focused
on how to make that experience easy for our users to manage multiple sites and so we're using containers for that and
obviously making sure that you know we are both time efficient with our customers time of stepping through the
common steps really efficiently as well as making sure that it's fault tolerant
and available is something that we've focused a ton of our time on so I heard you say that you are you're running with
containers and I believe you guys are using kubernetes so why did you choose kubernetes so we
standardized on kubernetes a few years ago we think it's a great open source reliable robust tool chain for deploying
scaling and managing applications and it's something that we have been using
broadly across you know pretty much everything we do so it's something that
we feel pretty comfortable with so I think you recently made announcement that you are moving the
majority of your workloads to AWS so why are you taking that step what challenges
that solving for you and your customers and why AWS yeah so some of the biggest challenges for us are deploying all of
our services in global locations around the world so Amazon obviously provides a lot more there than we'd be able to do
on our own I think we also have a high level of respect and Trust in Amazon's
ability to deliver reliable services so you know I think when it comes to things
like eks integrating well with things like elastic load balancing I am VPC
these are all capabilities that we're able to leverage for our customers without basically spending all of our
time doing the the nitty-gritty of the infrastructure work so what kind of tools are you using to work with your
with your kubernetes clusters so I mean where we basically built our own internal you know kubernetes management
system which is no trivial task as I'm sure that Amazon is found but has also worked through a leveraging we use a lot
of other tools whether it be prometheus fluent D these all work you know easily
with kubernetes so you've been able to use your same tools like Prometheus and fluent D with kind of regular option
kubernetes and you've been able to use the same ones at UK s yeah that's right and I think that's one of the big attractions for us about you know both
